'''Carbohydrate intake: ''''

Foods with a low glycaemic index are best eaten away from exercise

Foods with a high glycaemic index are best eaten close to exercise.


Fat intake should be reduced to allow for an increase in carbohydrate intake. Total fat intake should not be less than 20% of total energy intake (TEI).


'''Protein intake''' is essential for maintaining muscle mass

They are covered by the increase in total energy intake and depend on the type and level of physical activity:
{| class="wikitable"
|Moderate PA (3 times 30 to 60 min/week)
|Nutritional reference for the population 0.83 g/kg/day
|-
|Endurance sports
|1.2-1.4 g/kg/day (12-14% AET),

covered by ↑ of total energy intake
|-
|Maintenance of muscle mass
|1.3-1.5 g/kg/day
|-
|Increase in muscle mass
|Up to 2.5 g/kg/day (max. 6 months)

Protein supplements: maximum 1/3 of intake

not to exceed 1 g/kg/day
|}


Intake of water and electrolytes (NaCl) is essential, and must compensate for exercise-related losses.

Mineral and vitamin requirements are covered by a balanced diet.

question.title: Question
question.description: What is the optimal timing of carbohydrate intake in relation to exercise?

option_a.title: Option A
option_a.description: Carbohydrate intake should be reduced before exercise to prevent blood sugar spikes.

option_b.title: Option B
option_b.description: Foods with a low glycaemic index are best eaten after exercise to replenish glycogen stores.

option_c.title: Option C
option_c.description: Carbohydrate intake can be increased to up to 30% of total energy intake to support muscle growth.

option_d.title: Option D
option_d.description: Foods with a high glycaemic index are best eaten away from exercise to prevent hypoglycaemia.

correct_option.title: Correct Option
correct_option.description: Foods with a low glycaemic index are best eaten away from exercise
